entry.title: My Time
entry.content: My extra time doesn't have to be spent on only one thing. I'm so used to rushing through projects and completing things soon after I start them that I am having a hard time adjusting to a slower paced learning style.

entry.title: Immediate
entry.content:
What should I be working on right now? Is it enough for me to just be planning for the future when what is happening right now matters just as much?

My biggest dilemma is, one day I would like to own a company, but I need more money right now to support my family. Doing quick money tasks don't help my long term goals, and working on future ventures don't make me any money right now.

I think there are ways to minimize the effect, and be able to work on both things at once.

I've always pushed towards leading a minimalist life, one that actually makes things more convenient and effective while getting things out of your way.

I think that decreasing our lifestyle to ensure that we are living within our means is crucial. Our budget has little room for things that are outside of it, but yet every week we are eating out and not paying attention.

What I would like to do, is be able to bring in $1000 extra a month. I've talked about this before on this blog, but I need to revisit it.

I've got caught up in wanting to start my own business, which is a good thing and a bad thing. It's a good thing because I have goals and something to work towards. But, everything I put towards it I take away from my immediate income.

Making immediate money takes a lot of time and energy. It's something you don't necessarily want to do, but rather need to do. There are a few ways I could do this.

I tried my hand at freelance writing, and it sucked. But, if I get the payout, it wasn't so bad. But there are no guarantees. I've always thought about doing a PC repair and upkeep side business, but I hate the thought of spending all of my extra time on that. Also, that requires a lot of certifications.

I have also thought about doing web development on the side, which would be cool but it is hard to do complete websites without any design knowledge. I would need to be able to do things like make color palates, design icons and follow a design pattern for every job. I also don't really know how to connect to any web services, I just know how to make a standalone static site.

I have thought about writing apps, but those have no guarantees of being successful.

Anyhow, making extra money is difficult to do without structured employment. I've never entertained the thought of freelancing before now, and It's something that requires a lot of work before making a good amount of money.

This is something I'll be thinking about over the next few weeks.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 40: Transitioning
entry.content:
I think it has been hard trying to transition from my corporate job to an entrepreneurial position. My passion isn't into my corporate job, and my work has suffered for it.

I've never been one to keep a good conversation or just 'pop in' at work. I'm hesitant to talk about anything but work with my boss. I'm not exactly sure why, but that's how it is.

Some people I can talk to really easy. It's usually when they start talking to me though, not when I start talking to them.

My passion isn't in my engineering work anymore. I see how the people have worked for the company for years and years, and I feel like they have a lot of regrets. They have done the same thing for so many years, never leaving the position they are in.

Some people like that. That feeling of stability and security. Me, on the other hand, I prefer being on the cutting edge and creating my own path. I don't want to start a company for the money, I want to start one because I want to have control over my future.

I want my success to be a direct result of the effort that I put into it. I don't want to feel like I am capped or that I can't grow at the scale that I would like to.

At work, I feel trapped in my position. There is very little growth, yet lots of expectation. They say that they reward thinking outside of the box and individual creativity, but I've never heard of anyone who has climbed that ladder in this company.

If that ladder was available, surely I would climb it, and quickly. I would feel so much better about staying at the company if I actually had the tools and could choose the path that I see as necessary for the company.

There are a few things my company needs. In engineering, there is no way to track data, store it, and view it in an interactive way. I would love to develop a dashboard for that. Also, the process of transferring product from beginning to end is archaic and needs an overhaul similar to the data.

If they would let me work on these things, I might just want to stay. I feel that it's right up my creativity alley, and I would really enjoy doing it.

I am somewhat tired of the weird, one-off I/O applications that I have to write at work. I'd rather build something that everyone could use and everyone could interact with.

Web technologies are the future. It's inevitable. That's the only thing that connects all of the things we use every day. If the company won't let me progress them to that point, then I won't keep working there.

The other bad thing is, I can only work 40 hours and never get any overtime. When I need more money, this sucks. Working part-time on something else sucks, because the $/hour rate is way lower than my corporate work rate.

Also, Corning is a great company. Part of my beef is with the division I am in. It lags behind all of the other industries that Corning operates in, so that sucks. I want to be a part of the best of the best.

I don't like feeling stuck, yet that's how I feel. I'm grateful for where I am and the opportunities I have been given, but I really need to get out from under the weight of my student loans / working for the man. I need to have better control over my future.

If I am still at Corning in more than 5 years, something is seriously wrong. Like, I gave up on my dreams and am full of regret, wrong.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 39: Monkey Wrench
entry.content:
When Google get's involved, it's probably time to get out of that market.

Google has come out with a new front end interface for podcasts built into it's Google Play Music app. That's not good for my idea.

That means, Google has bought in to the way Podcasts are operated the way they are now. It means they didn't think it was necessary to revolutionize the whole market. Why should I?

I still think it would be really valuable to build the web application that I want to build. I need to build a portfolio for myself. But as a business? It might be a losing battle. I might not be looking far enough into the future.

The way Podcasts are run are yesterday's technologies. They are only becoming more popular today because of the accessibility people have to larger data caps and faster cellular networks.

There are other things that are the future. Things like IoT, VR, AI. The best thing I could do for a business would involve one, if not all, of these technologies. That would create a platform that is revolutionary and future proof.

The nice thing about learning the web development tools, is that it's free and I can implement whatever I want if I take the time to do it. You can't do that with hardware based ideas.

All of this learning is still so valuable. Working hard won't always bring success, but success won't come without me working hard.

Things are good. I need to figure out how to make some more money quick, but things are good.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 38: Time
entry.content:
Time is a tool. It's also a gift, a reminder and a limit.

Time is a lot of things, and it's really up to us how we use it and manage it.

I often don't like to think about time, because that requires effort and maintenance. It's as if I can ignore it and it will leave me alone.

But the best thing I can do with my time is pay attention and manage it properly. It takes work, care and a plan to truly make the most of the time given to us.

I'm becoming more obsessed with the thought of not wasting any of my time and putting it all towards the things that are most important to me. Things like family and work and learning.

But I also want to be flexible to allocate for the priorities at hand. I don't want to make decisions based on what I want to do more than I want to make decisions based on what matters most in that moment.

Sometimes, working hard and earning a living matters most in a give moment. Sometimes, spending specific time with my wife and communicating with her is most important. One day, taking time out of every day to spend with my kids will be a very important part of my time.

I want to make the most of what I have. I don't want to waste what I have been given. That would be a shame. I wouldn't be able to live with myself. I would die a regretful man.

I don't want to hack my time as if it is only a tool, it's a gift that should be shared. I don't want to treat it as if it is endless, because we all know it's not.

As the saying goes, "Time will tell...". Time will tell what your priorities have been and what kind of a person you have become as a result. I want to make sure that my time honors my legacy with pride.

I like to think about how many successful and influential people have the same amount of time in a day as I do. It's the one thing that levels the playing field. If they can do what they have done with the time they have been given, so can I.

I want to be the hardest working person I know, but I also want to be the best father, husband and friend that I know. It's a tough balance. Sometimes I will get it wrong, but time will tell.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 37: Ideas
entry.content:
I have a lot of ideas. I'm not sure where they come from, but I write them down anyways.

Most of my ideas are pretty terrible. I haven't thought them through all of the way before I start thinking about how I could implement them.

But some of my ideas, they are really good. I get really excited about them, and I only wish that I could turn them into something real.

That's why I am working so hard to learn the necessary tools to have the ability to bring my ideas to life. I can't afford to have someone else do it for me, and often times the best way to get something done, and down well, is to do it yourself.

I'm not a genius, I'm not a mad scientist, I just work hard and learn fast. I can go from zero to semi-pro in about anything I learn in no time. That's part of why I have so much confidence in my ability to tackle my huge ideas.

I also have ideas for other people, whether or not they like it. It's not that I know best for them, but I like to think about what I would do with the tools that they have been given and the opportunities they have.

I like my ideas, they keep me moving forward. But, my ideas are crap if I can't act on them. If I cant put action to my words then they are worthless. That's a constant struggle that I always have to overcome.

That's why I strive so hard to learn and grow. It's the only way I know how to push my ideas beyond the realm of just being ideas.

I don't always plan on being the one that does the work. That's a method that can only grow as much as I can. I also need to be good about delegating my work once I have the resources.

I'm acting on one of my ideas right now and I am loving it. It gives me even more of a reason to get up early in the morning.

I can't wait to get to the point where I will have a product with customers that will allow me to grow my idea into a scaling business that will be able to make a difference in the world.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 36: Learning
entry.content:
I'll never stop learning, and I won't ever stop seeking knowledge.

There will come a point, though, when I will use my knowledge more than I seek it. I can't wait to see where I will be when that day comes.

Right now, learning the tools I need to start the platform that I want to start, I feel so enabled. I feel like I could create anything that I ever wanted to create.

My platform won't be easy, but it's totally doable. I get more confident everyday that I will be able to complete the base platform on my own before seeking out investments/employees/customers.

Both Hannah and I are in a learning state. She is learning about the tools and methods she should use to approach her path that she wants to take. It's awesome to see.

My biggest problem right now is that I need to continue working hard in every are of my life, and not just in the learning that I need to further my dreams.

I need to make sure I am exercising hard, praying/reading/fasting hard, eating healthy, growing my relationship with Hannah, and working hard at my current employment.

I haven't been exercising lately, and I'm not really sure why. I'd really like to fast and lose a few pounds while I'm at it. I never successfully completed the fast the last time I tried it but I know I want to.

I could afford to lose about 20 pounds. I would like to lose the fat, but gain muscle in return.

Here's a wild idea that I'd like to try: I'd like to go vegetarian and take protein supplements to increase my muscle mass. Would that be healthy? I'd have to do some research on it. But that would allow me to keep the fat off and increase my muscle gains.

That's be crazy, but I do really want to be healthy and make it a focus of mine to increase my strength.

No matter what, I'll keep learning and growing and shifting my focuses.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 35: Flexibility
entry.content:
I find it interesting when I look at the motivations that I have behind wanting to start my own business. In the short term, I want to be out of debt. I want to be able to support my family and begin building wealth.

But I think this drive goes much deeper than that. It more fits my personality, something that is flexible but stable, something that I created myself. Something I can strive for and push towards everyday.

In my mind, I'd like to be able to work wherever I am in the world. I don't want to take vacations, but rather trips that still allow me to be productive. Sitting on a beach gets old for me really quick.

To me, trips are more about experiences than relaxation. I can relax just fine at home. I want to travel for the sake of having unforgettable experiences and see things I never would have seen had I been relaxing.

But I also want that flexibility in my everyday life. I want to be able to exercise, see my kids and talk with my wife in the mornings. I want to live close to work, so that I can make sure the commute isn't an excuse for not seeing them often.

I want to work hard, though, and that will require some late nights for seasons and it will require a lot of my attention. That's part of the reason why I need to waste none of my extra time. I need to spend any extra time on the things that are most important to me.

I don't want 'work' to define me, but I want to be defined as a hard worker. I want to be the hardest working person I know. Both at work, and in the home. I want my kids to see that they need to work hard to achieve their dreams. Not only that, I want to teach them that it's a good thing to have dreams and that they should feel like anything is possible.

I want to teach them to learn for themselves, to love other people and build meaningful relationships. I want to teach them that they have control over the path that their life takes, and that it's not dependent on anything in their past.

I want to have the flexibility to play that role in my kid's lives.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 34: Next Step
entry.content:
I can't always focus on the big picture, sometimes I just need to focus on the next step.

That's Hannah's advice, anyways, and it makes sense. Last night after explaining some of my biggest ideas to friends I started to feel scared and intimidated by it all.

I'm ambitious, I'm not just going to settle for something that isn't the best that I can do. But, even my visions are too big for me sometimes. That's when I just need to sit down and figure out what's next.

What's next? Learning the tools I need to start building my platform. That's what I'm currently doing. I plan on having the platform done in 3-4 months (for launching, that is).

I will need to spend a few months promoting, advertising and getting my platform out there before I start a KickStarter to fund some of the platform. During this time I will continue to refine the platform and develop phone / tablet applications.

It is crazy to think that I will be doing this on my own. "Hey, my name is Jordan and I'm the CEO, lead developer and head marketer of XYZ." To see my vision come to fruition I will definitely need people.

But, right now, I need to keep my head down and press forward. I'm in a learning phase, and I will be for a long time, even after launching.

In other news, I'm super excited for our baby to come in to the world in August. I'm totally ready to take on that role and still continue to grow in every area of my life. I don't see it as a burden, but a reminder that I need to be more vigilant than ever.

I want to be able to continue working just as hard when i have to get up in the middle of the night to care for the baby. I want to cherish those moments, not regret them.

I'm excited about a lot of things now a days. Things are moving forward really fast and I enjoy growing everyday instead of remaining stagnate.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 33: All of the Peices
entry.content:
I really think that all of the pieces need to be in place for me to be successful everyday.

There needs to be a balance, things that keep other things in check so that I don't get off track. For example, my exercise is what helps me keep focus during the day and sleep well at night.

Eating healthy will allow me to stay healthy and keep off the weight that I can gain really easily.

Those two things combined will help me maintain a physical balance that will lead to success.

Reading my Bible will help me stay focused on what is most important in life and keep me spiritually grounded.

Planning my days will allow me to think less about what I should be doing and do more of what I plan on doing.

Loving my wife and spending time with her daily allows me to remain emotionally stable and keep me light.

There are little things that happen every day that lead to a successful life, and that's what I am aiming for.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 32: Habits
entry.content:
I've been in a great habit of getting up on time. It has helped me be more productive about moving towards owning my own business, and furthering my skills in web development.

I think I could stand to do more planning about what will specifically get done every morning. Sometimes I get up and whatever I start working on I just end up spending all of my time on it even if it isn't a high priority task.

This would help me get a better sense of when I will get things done, as well as how long it will take me to get it done. I think that's an awesome trait to have for an entrepreneur. 

Once I finish the Udemy course, I am going to begin working on building a new podcasting service. It will allow podcasters to host their content for free, and have ads managed by my software. It will allow the entry costs to be zero, and they can spend their time doing the things they like to do.

I'd like to run that for at least a year and see if I can gain traction. If I can gain enough traction and make enough money to make a profit, I could even begin investing in the business and hire employees. 

That's all a dream, but it's entirely possible. I was thinking today about how I will need to learn how the ad industry works, as well as how I will manage all of the hosting I will need for the podcasts.

I am tending towards having more good habits than bad. One bad habit I have had lately is my eating. It has sucked. I need to change that.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 31: One Month
entry.content:
One month of blogging everyday. That's pretty cool!

It has been a pretty cool journey for me. Blogging consistently has helped me start facing my dreams and get moving. It has motivated me to follow written goals.

I think now that we're at one month, it's a good time to check in on my goals for this year (6 months?). Here they are again:

Career: I will increase my work rate by limiting distractions from social media / entertainment starting now. I also will build relationships with co-workers by taking scheduled breaks at 10:30 AM and 2:30 PM.

Financial: I will make at least $1000 a month on top of my salary building tools via web/app development by November 2016 (6 months).

Spiritual: I am going to read my Bible/meditate/pray for at least 30 minutes a day starting now into eternity.

Physical: Run a half marathon on September 18th, 2016 at a pace of 8:30 min/mile. I have this planned out via MapMyRun.

Intellectual: I will learn the skills I need to complete my financial goal. I will do this by taking online classes, reading books and finding internet solutions. I will dedicate at least 30 minutes a day to this task starting now.

Family: I will practice giving undivided attention to my wife everyday starting now. I also will do the same for my kids when I have them. (Is this really a goal? I might need to come up with something better.)

Social: I will research time management by reading books and doing research so that I can schedule regular time to enjoy with my friends (and extended family). I would like to spend at least an hour at the beginning of the week on this task.

This is a great list, and I think I have done well with them. I've struggled with the career goal, I've been inconsistent with the physical goal, and my social goal could always use improvement. I'm crushing my financial, intellectual, spiritual and family goals.

So, how do I improve on the goals that I am falling behind on? I think that comes down to accountability and discipline. I could stand to have my ENTIRE day planned out the day before. That way I can't have any lazy excuses when something doesn't get done.

I still don't know if I like working out in the afternoon. I think that if I were to workout in the mornings it would get done more consistently. In the afternoons I never know how I will be feeling after a day at work, and there is often something going on right after work so the time isn't consistent.

If I were to work out in the mornings, I think I would do it between 6:45 and 7:15 AM. I think a half hour is plenty for now, and I don't need to start getting ready for work until 7:30. That puts my morning routine like this:

5:00 - 5:30 Wake up, make coffee, sit at desk and dive into Bible study along with praying.
5:30 - 6:45 Business/Educational hour.
6:45 - 7:15 Work out. 
7:15 - 8:00 Shower and get ready for work, and eat breakfast.

Thats a solid morning, and it doesnt change much of what I am currently doing. This will help improve my physical routine.

Live intentionally. Plan your future. Work harder than anyone you know.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 30: Organizing
entry.content:
I've been writing all of this stuff down in my blog, but I have't been writing it down where I can see it everyday.

I should be writing my goals down somewhere where I will be able to review them and check against them every day. Something like the background of my phone, or on the new tab of my web browser.

I should also be using Todoist to break down my goals into smaller chunks. It's good for putting in dependency tasks and flexible with the timeline.

I also should be planning my morning hours more specifically the day/night before. I should know exactly what I am going to work on and how long I'm going to work on it.

I still am unsure about the time-frame of my morning hours. I think in an ideal world I would like to work out in the mornings, but I also don't want to spend time away from Hannah in the evenings doing work. I want to be investing time into our relationship when she is available.

I am getting up at 5 everyday this week. That means I basically have 2 hours to work before I have to go to work. 1 hour should be Bible time, the other should be work/studying time for my freelance writing and web development.

I like to start paragraphs with 'I'. Maybe because I am talking about myself?

I think eventually I would like to turn this blogging habit into a lifestyle blog. Something that motivates people to follow their dreams, gets them out of their comfort zones and makes them think.

It would be awesome to have a following of people that I could use to make waves in this world. Once you have followers, you can use that momentum to become successful in a lot of areas.

We got a new desk last night. Something functional, minimalist and that inspires productivity. I think it will help me get more organized about how I spend my time when I am doing work at home.

Hannah will be using the desk as well. She will be using it to start her online business, or to put time into her non-profit that she dreams about everyday. One day we will both have desks that we can operate from.

She has a passion for helping people, and she has a passion surrounding taboo and controversial issues that aren't being talked about the right way. Things like how pornography affects the world, and tackling the root causes of why people think they want abortions.

She's a dreamer, and I can only hope that any company I would found can have as much empathy and passion that she does about what it is trying to achieve.

I think I will be organizing the next day right before bed. It will allow me to be a bit more dynamic based on the time I go to bed. I think specifying not only how much time I will spend on things, but exactly what I will be working on will be very helpful.

Getting organized is something I don't think I am a natural at. I tend to not plan ahead and just take things as they come. In the past this worked fine because opportunities would come left and right and I could adapt quickly.

Now, I am the one that needs to create the opportunities for myself. So if I am not planning and organizing my path, then there will be no opportunities for growth and prosperity down the pipeline.

This was a good blog post.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 29: On Productivity
entry.content:
Today was a pretty productive day. Mostly because I had it all planned out.

That's how I want everyday to be in the future. I want it to be planned out, calculated, so that I don't waste the time that I have. I don't want to be extremely rigid, but I want it to be planned.

This can apply to the workplace as well. I would like to make sure I have a set number of things that I should complete during the work day.

I did some math today, and I figured out that if I reached my goal of an extra $1000 a month, I could get out of debt in five years. Five years! That would be incredible. Even more motivation to get this done.

Our cars would be payed off within the next year. Credit cards in a few months. It would be amazing to be operating at that level.

I like to write, and I don't mind writing creatively. I have found that there are sites what will pay you to write freelance for them. I found a site called Listverse that will pay you $100 per article, with 10 facts and at least 1500 words.

I could write several articles a week for that publication and not even bat an eye at it. There would be no learning curve, it would just flow out of me. I think I might start looking into all of my options as a freelance writer.

In the meantime, I will continue to learn and grow in the web development sphere. I have to keep moving along in the Udemy class that I purchased. I also need to find other things to apply my new-found skills to so that I can start building a portfolio.

One idea that I had today - a podcast service that was like youtube. It's not a new idea, but I'm surprised it doesn't exist. There is no service out there that allows you to host podcasts for free, all while managing the ad sphere for you.

Today was a good day, I'll be getting up early to keep working.

I'm going to be the hardest working person I know.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 28: Pressing On
entry.content:
I've been at this for several weeks, and it feels good.

Right about now is when I really need to hunker down and continue the race. It's easy for me to stagnate a bit and lose my focus. I think this blog is helping me with that.

I have been able to get my ideas out of my head and somewhere where I can look back at them. Could I be writing it in a journal? Sure, but that's something I just couldn't get in a habit of doing.

Blogging "publicly" has allowed me to be more transparent, all while holding me more accountable. I can't just not do the things I will say I need to do.

I'm prepared to work harder this week at work than any other week before, because work now has a purpose in my plan. In the past few months, it didn't fit into my plan. I thought I needed to start a business today and drop everything.

Now I know I can't do that. Because of that, working "for the man" is a huge part of my plan to get out of debt and prosper. Not only that, but higher education is on the table as well.

If I can go back to school for two years and get a masters degree, I could make more at Corning and even further accelerate my debt payoff.

But, working full time, going to grad school, freelancing on the side, having a baby and managing to spend any time doing anything else outside of that would be crazy. I'm into it, though.

Right now is a time in my life when I need to hustle. I need to be working harder than I ever have and ever will in the future. I have life in my bones, and time on my hands. It's about time I used it to my advantage.

Getting serious about my debt payoff and generating a winning attitude are very important things to me. I want my family to be very successful and I think we have a lot to show the world.

I really want to include Hannah into my success story because she has so much to offer. I think that she has so much potential to make a huge impact on the world. I want to support her as much as I possibly can.

I also want to make sure I am on the same page with her in regards to our debt payoff. We both need to be tackling it hardcore if we want to get this thing out of the way. I know I am ready for it.

This blog has helped me a lot. I need to continue to do the things I say I will do.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 27: Success
entry.content:
What's my definition of success? I think there are a few things.

I think first and foremost my definition of success is having the option to work how I want to work and not be forced into a work situation because I need a paycheck.

I also think success is being able to provide for my family in a way that contributes to their success and keeps them healthy. I want them to feel like they can live a purposeful life of their choosing without feeling like money is a prohibiting factor.

I also think that success is being able to have deep relationships with the people that I love without work getting in the way. I want to be able to enjoy the time I have with others, and be able to invest in their lives in a meaningful way.

That sounds like a dream job. Something that pays well, allows for flexibility and doesn't get in the way of things that mean a lot to me.

I think it would be hard to find a job like that without creating it yourself. Everything would have to be on my terms, but it would also have to be valuable enough to bode a decent income.

Once I am out of debt and have less restrictions on where my income is spent I can have freedoms like this. Until then, I need to be the hardest working person I know, hustling at every chance.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 26: When You Can't Be an Entrepreneur
entry.content:
I've been listening to Gary V lately, he says you can't be an entrepreneur if you have a full time job.

I think he's right. Though, he was caught off guard by the question. He had just realized that some people have to have some way to transition out of a normal paying job into the one they want.

His basic statement was that you have the potential to be an entrepreneur if you feel choked out by working for someone. He also is adamant about making sure you don't listen to what anyone else says you can't do.

When I was in college, I had a friend who had started his own business. He had made an app. It never sold more than a few times, but it was cool and I admired him for the effort he put in.

I told him once that I would one day like to start a company. He responded by saying it was a ton of work and not really worth the effort. This moment stayed with me for several years.

Back then I didn't listen to the right people. I didn't think for myself. I was green, very new to the idea of being in the real world.

Entrepreneurship isn't easy. Successful entrepreneurs make it look easy, but it's not. There is a lot that has to go right for and entrepreneur to be successful.

Right now, I can't be an entrepreneur. I'm working a full time job. It's a default by definition.

But, one day, I will be an entrepreneur. It's what I crave. I still have that wide-eyed sense that I had back in the day when I was told that I shouldn't start my own business.

I feel like I am suffocating working at a corporate job. It's so stagnate. So normal. So average. I want to be way more than average, I want to be my best me.

I want to take life by the horns and show the world what I can do. I feel like I have so much more to offer than what I am currently doing. I am just getting started.

My plan right now is to not be an entrepreneur. Why? Because I have bills to pay, mouth(s) to feed, debt to pay off. I plan on freelancing extra income to get my debt paid off so I can live a life with minimal expenses and put all of my time towards creating a business.

Without my debt, my family could easily live on less than $2000 a month. That's less than half of what I make now. Imagine if I was able to use that extra income and put it to work for me rather than just using it to pay for my past debts.

With debt, I need a high paying job to get by. Without it, I have freedom to choose where I want to spend my time and energy and I can really have a grasp on what the future holds for me.

I have a spirit of faith that says that I can be successful, I can be wealthy, and I can love what I do. I will show everyone that I have the spirit of faith by saving money, paying off debt and creating my own path.

It's only a matter of time. I am serious about this.

Jordan

link.title: Day 26: When You Can't Be an Entrepreneur

entry.title: Day 25: New Day
entry.content:
Yesterday was awesome at work.

I got stuff done, plain and simple. I think the main motivation was a podcast that was recommended to me by my pastor at church. The specific podcast episode is linked here.

It motivated me because it talked about having a spirit of faith, and how success is tied to it. It talked about how walking with God isn't free, and that it isn't easy. I've gotta put in the work to expect a result.

It helped yesterday as well that I was finally able to work on a project that was on hold. I think getting that project under my belt will be great and I can move on from it.

I purchased a Udemy web development course and it's awesome. I already know quite a bit about HTML and CSS so those sections are flying by. It's a great course that will allow me to do some neat things.

I want to build a web server at work that connects to remote SQL Server databases and plots the data using ChartJS. As long as I can connect remotely to the PCs, then I should be able to do it easily.

I think by doing this in my spare time I can show the people above me at work more of what i can do, and what I can contribute to the workplace. I also would like to develop a better internal homepage.

I also want to build a church member tracking tool for church. They are using one right now that isn't that complicated and they pay $10 a month for the service. I could do the same thing and make it free.

I also could make it better and sell it just like they do. I could add more advanced features and integrate a lot more things into the web app.

I'm feeling really motivated. It's great to be working in a direction that is more inline with what I want out of life. Things are good right now.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 24: Less Entertainment
entry.content:
I can't be focused at work when I am jumping on YouTube or any social media every 30 minutes. 

I'm not sure why I got into the habit of watching YouTube at work. I think it was a combination of a lack of interaction with people, and having my cube be moved to a place that has less people that work with me. 

It's killing my productivity and my motivation to be proactive at work. The only time I get anything done is the day that it's due. 

Most of the things I have to do lately aren't that difficult or time consuming, so I procrastinate until the last minute to get it done.

I also have a hard time talking to people about progress outside of meetings. Something will come up in a meeting and I sometimes get a hint of 'why didn't you tell me that earlier?'. 

These things are making work miserable for me. It makes me not want to go in to work. Just kinda sucks.

All of this is in my control, therefore I can change all of it. I have touted about moving my cube back to where I used to be, but I don't know if that is entirely necessary. 

I should be able to thrive wherever I am. I should be able to be accountable wherever I am. I should be able to be productive wherever I am. It's just that simple.

I can't have excuses about my situation when my path is entirely in my control. Regardless of the progress I make outside of work, I still have to show up at work. I should make the most of it.

I really need to set up a meeting with my engineering manager. It's been too long.

I will be proactive about it and do it today.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 23: Emphasis
entry.content:
I put a lot of emphasis on my progress outside of work, and that's okay. But it's not okay if I'm not doing well at work.

I spend a lot of time thinking about how I will make more money outside of work, how to improve myself outside of work, and my work has suffered because of it.

I'm still stuck in my current situation - somewhat isolated from my old group of engineers. I really want to get back to working with them and get out of the current group I am working in.

I also haven't been looking into how I can make more money at work. Honestly, I know that if I was the hardest worker in the building, they probably would pay me more. I could ask for a raise at a moment's notice.

Is that how I should be approaching this? Should I continue to invest in ways to make more money outside of work, when there is a potential that I could be killing it right where I am at?

I had these questions yesterday when I was sitting at my desk. I mean, a consistent job truly is a great thing. It's up to me to make the most of it. I really should be emphasizing my focus on it since my job is the reason I can put food on the table everyday.

My biggest problem is, I hate how much time it is going to take me to pay off my debt and save for a home and start a business. We're talking like 10 years minimum. That's a long time!

I feel like I can't settle into a routine unless I am making headway towards accelerating my debt payoff. I feel like it's something that I need to do.

I'm pretty sick of making a good salary, yet living paycheck to paycheck. There has to be some ways that I can make more for my family so that we can get this debt paid off sooner rather than later.

Doing something other than what comes naturally to you is really hard. This whole freelancing thing isn't natural to me. Engineering is natural to me.

I think I will talk to my engineering manager about all of this. He seems to be very understanding. I don't bug him much, but maybe I should. I'd like to get his input about how i can make some changes at work.

I'm not a bad worker, but I'm in a bad spot. Something isn't jiving with me. I need to be moving forward both at work and outside of work.

Keep moving forward.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 22: Begin
entry.content:
Discipline is easy when you don't have any other choice.

The easiest way for me to be more disciplined is when I set rules that force me to be more productive when I need to be productive.

After talking it over with Hannah, I have set explicit rules stating that I will be reading for an hour, and working on my freelance business for an hour each morning before work. The evenings are off limits for business ventures.

Since the evenings are off limits, and she is on board with that, I can't break that rule. It would detract from the seriousness of my move towards being more disciplined and productive.

The evenings will be filled with running, dinner and Hannah time. Or, anything else we have planned that evening. I will be going to sleep between 10 and 10:30, and waking up at 5:30 every day.

That gives me 2 hours before needing to get ready to go for work. Reading my Bible and praying will be first, since it is most important. Business comes after.

I also have dedicated some of my lunch time at work for studying and working on business ventures. I don't know how much I like that, since there are a lot of things that usually eat into my lunch time, but at least I will know what to do if there is nothing going on at lunch.

Time management and planning are crucial tools that I will need to learn for my freelance business. Having a work schedule spelled out so there are no 'blurring of the lines' and the rules are clean cut will help me be more productive and responsible about billing my time accurately. 

So, today I am beginning that disciplined schedule. I woke up at 5:30 and began studying. Now I am transitioning over to my business work time. It feels good, and it is great to feel like I'm not taking any time away from time that I could be spending with Hannah.

Also, my food eating habits have been atrocious lately. I need to knock that off and get healthier. I think I will try to have a minimal meat and no sugar diet. It's just so terrible for me and my health. I have a little bit of a pot belly and that needs to go away.

I also wanted to try to take at least 5 minutes every morning and do push-ups and sit-ups. Maybe in the future I will add on to that so I am doing strength conditioning every morning. 

Jordan

entry.title: Day 21: Dissapointed
entry.content:
Open source software failed me today.

It's not their fault. It's not like they are getting paid to develop the application. I can't expect anything from something that I didn't pay for.

I feel like I would love to give back to the open source community if I felt that I had any relevant experience. Let me explain.

I have no experience writing user-oriented applications. I have only ever written math/manufacturing applications. The type of applications that most open-source project involve are for a consumer. 

I also don't have a lot of experience with writing graphics/processor intensive tasks. So something like a video processor or encoder is something I would have to learn a lot about before attempting. 

It's 2 AM. I should sleep.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 20: Reality
entry.content:
I don't think I can start my business today. Or any time soon for that matter.

I need to make more money by hustling at the moment. I need to pay off my debt and be done with it. Since I want to cash-flow my business, I want to be debt free before I start.

That means my business will probably be in something different than the last blog post. It will be similar, but in the time that passes someone else will fill that market, I guarantee it. 

Starting a business wasn't on my list of goals, making more money is. I guess I should make sure I reference my list often.

There are three ways I can make more money. Freelancing, developing and teaching. I can freelance web-development, develop my own apps and sell them, or teach courses on how to make apps/develop in different languages. 

Freelance is a lot of work. I would need Hannah's help to organize clients and manage. Developing my own apps would require a stroke of luck to actually make a decent amount on them, so I don't think I will be doing that, and teaching is definitely on the table.

Creating online courses is the cheapest way to make the most profit. I would need to invest time in learning things that are both relevant and useful. I use LabWindows at work everyday, but that's not something most people need. 

I think I would like to potentially do both freelancing and creating online courses. I've never done either, but it would be a cool adventure. I think that I could be a neat thing to track my progress and build a path that others could follow to make extra money on the side. 

It would also be neat to have people that I could send emails to about how to make money on the side. It only takes 1000 people to have a platform for success. When you have that many people listening, you've made it.

I'll start looking into proper freelancing, learning tools to do that, and also I will pick a specific path that I would start teaching.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 19: How do I actually do this?
entry.content:
So, yesterday I talked about what type of business that I would like to own. It's something I am good at, and passionate about.

Bu how do I actually do that? How do I start working on a business from scratch when I have a 40hr/week salary job? Is it feasible to start slowly and work towards something? Do I need to freelance some of my other time to cash-flow the business?

These are some important questions, ones that I will need to figure out. I think that some of these questions will be addressed in my EntreLeadership book, and I am listening to a lot of content from Seth Godin on starting a business. 

But there is a big difference between knowing what to do and actually doing it. That's what makes businesses successful, or fail really quickly. It takes a tenacity and a gut that does the right thing, always.

What I'm finding is that the relationships and trust you build into your brand is much more important than the product you produce. It's about the story, the love and passion that drives you and your business that gives you an edge. 

It's also about monopoly, which would be very tough in the market I would like to get into. But, like Seth says, no one is forcing you to go into the market you choose. That is something I will need to think about.

It seems daunting how much goes into starting a business, but I wouldn't be able to live with myself if I didn't try. 

A few people in the past have tried to discourage me from starting a business. They say it's too hard, and that it consumes your life. I don't mind working hard and long, so long as the freedom of a path that I have chosen for myself is replaced with it.

I don't think I can live this safely for the rest of my life. There is no challenge to it. It was way too easy to get where I am today. It wasn't the best path, but it was the safe path for sure.

The safe path never really was for me. I'm on the path to success.

Jordan

link.title: Day 19: How do I actually do this?

entry.title: Day 18: Business
entry.content:
I really want to start a business.

I'm good at making things talk to each other. I'm good at integrating software and hardware. I want to start an internet of things company for industrial businesses.

Right now, manufacturing software sucks. I see it first hand every day. I get paid because I can do it, but doing it results in some of the most ugly and non-intelligent programming on earth. Why does everyone have their own standard for communicating?

I love the concept of Google's Brillo and Weave ventures. It makes so much sense. Let's put all of the devices that talk to each other on the same platform so they can interact with each other in the most optimal way.

I really wish I was on the teams developing that product, but I am not. But, I can start a business selling advanced and modern industrial IoT devices to manufacturers with the intent of eventually supporting the open and secure infrastructure that Google is fronting.

I think I would like to start by tackling the data acquisition market. The only reason I think that is because I have a ton of exposure to it, and national instruments holds a monopoly. They do a good job, but I could do it better. LabView is an industry standard. It does amazing things, but it is hideous and is almost impossible to scale. It's spaghetti code, and most of the people that use it can't wield its true power.

I want to create an elegant solution that is robust enough for the industrial environment, but has the aesthetic edge of the modern web/app design architecture. I want to have a solution that works out of the box, something that has extensive simplicity and compatibility. I want to make a solution that allows developers to create powerful applications without needing to worry about scale and their user interface.

Since this is an IIoT company, all solutions will be accessible to anyone who has access/is interested and the data should be configured in a way that is accessible and can be viewed in ways that brings the most value to the end user. I want data to be accessible on any platform. Mobile, desktop, tablet, and web.

To me this sounds amazing, and it solves problems that real engineers struggle with every day. It sounds like the future, and it could help minimize the cost of developing complex applications for industries that need to use these tools to measure and verify products.

This isn't my only idea. But it is the one that resonates with me the most. It's something I have dealt with over the past 3 years and I think I can do it better than the tools that I use currently.

Honestly I am just excited to get started on something that solves real problems. I like to build tools. Tools that help other people achieve really cool things. That's what I want to do.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 17: It's a Boy
entry.content:
I'm having a baby boy, folks!

Today my wife and I had the 20 week ultrasounds to check the vitals of our baby and determine the gender. Let's just say it was quite obvious.

It's crazy to think that I will be fathering a son soon. I can't wait. By that time I will be more productive than ever, because I will need to be.

I will need to be sacrificially ready and available for my family, so I can't afford to slack off. I want to be running my future company by that time, and eventually I would like to get to the point where I can spend time with them and work as well.

To me, I think working is a very important aspect of life. I think that my kids should be a part of that journey. I think they should know how working hard is good for them, and that they too should work hard for the life they want to live.

I want to father my kids under the impression that they truly can be anything they want to be in the world. I want to show them that they can make their own path, and that the people they surround themselves with will impact them the most.

But I also want my kids to be creating and making, not consuming constantly. I want them to get their hands dirty, use their brains, and be inspired to grow everyday.

I want to have an awesome legacy to pass on to my kids, so that they can carry the torch and change the world.

I want to change the world.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 16: Breaking Down
entry.content:
Let's attempt to break down that financial/intellectual goal.

After much, much deliberation, I have decided that I like to build tools. I like being able to enable people to accomplish the things that they want to do in a better and more appealing way.

That's why I like where I work. I get to build and develop test bench hardware/software so that operators can use them to measure and verify product. I like to make the experience for the operator one that allows them to not even notice that it is there.

I want to get into web development. It's the future (and right now). I want to be able to build tools for other people that are useful and well polished. I come up with ideas all of the time, but I need to sit down one day and actually implement them.

I don't like dealing directly with people, so that's why contracting/consulting web development just isn't up my alley. It's easiest to get started in, but it would get old fast.

I don't think I want to do web development for another company. I think I would get the feeling of being stuck and carrying out someone else's vision. I'd rather start my own company surrounding my own tool that is a part of my vision for myself.

One big potential market is writing software for church management. There are only a few players, and that sector could use some fresh talent. It's useful for me too because I am currently going to a startup church, and they could use some management software.

Other than that, the thing that I would have the most experience in is development in IoT tools, Data acquisition and management tools, and sensor I/O tools. I think an ideal platform for me to develop on would be something like a Raspberry PI, or a BeagleBone.

These are just some ideas, but I need to act quickly. I want to be making $1000 a month in just 6 months. Time is ticking away.

I think that I should spend a solid 2 months developing my craft. I would like to learn an online platform (AngularJS/React/Ruby On Rails), and app development for IoT purposes. This is also the time that I would need to come up with an idea for an application.

I think then I would like to spend about a month developing an application that I would hope to build a small business around.

Then, I would like to spend the last three months setting up my business and getting my first customers. 

This could all change dramatically, I am just trying to play it all out. I need to get it all written down somewhere so I have somewhere to come back to.

I want to start my own company. It's been a dream of mine for a long time. Even if I fail this time, I will learn a lot and I can apply it to my future endeavors. 

Jordan

entry.title: Day 15: Refining
entry.content:
I'm reading Dave Ramsey's book called EntreLeadership, and I am using it to help refine my goals.

Goals must be specific and measurable. They also must have a time limit.

There are seven generic areas that we can improve in our lives, they are:
  1. Career
  2. Financial
  3. Spiritual
  4. Physical
  5. Intellectual
  6. Family
  7. Social

Remarkably, my goals were pretty well spread across these areas. And, some of them actually had specificity to them. Let's review my goals:
  1. I'm going to run a half marathon on September 18th.
  2. Make at least $1000 a month on top of my salary.
  3. I'm going to read more.
  4. I want to exponentially increase my work rate at my employment.
  5. I want to continue to deepen my relationship with my wife, family, and friends.
  6. Time management.
Some of these are well planned, most are not.

Career: I will increase my work rate by limiting distractions from social media / entertainment starting now. I also will build relationships with co-workers by taking scheduled breaks at 10:30 AM and 2:30 PM.

Financial: I will make at least $1000 a month on top of my salary building tools via web/app development by November 2016 (6 months).

Spiritual: I am going to read my Bible/meditate/pray for at least 30 minutes a day starting now into eternity.

Physical: Run a half marathon on September 18th, 2016 at a pace of 8:30 min/mile. I have this planned out via MapMyRun.

Intellectual: I will learn the skills I need to complete my financial goal. I will do this by taking online classes, reading books and finding internet solutions. I will dedicate at least 30 minutes a day to this task starting now. 

Family: I will practice giving undivided attention to my wife everyday starting now. I also will do the same for my kids when I have them. (Is this really a goal? I might need to come up with something better.)

Social: I will research time management by reading books and doing research so that I can schedule regular time to enjoy with my friends (and extended family). I would like to spend at least an hour at the beginning of the week on this task. 

This is an awesome list. Having these written out explicitly will help me a lot in the long run. I need to put them in a place where I can be reminded of them regularly. 

Some of these goals are quite easy, and some of them are hardly goals, but this is a big step for me in living my life intentionally. 

I would like to have goals for myself in all of these categories at least every 6 months so that I can continually refine myself and be a bit more dynamic than having goals for a whole year. 

Once I finish / am completing these goals, I think it would be smart to set some more long term goals for all of these categories. It would be nice to have long term goals and be able to break them down into bite sized chunks. 

This is awesome!

Jordan

entry.title: Day 14: Destroyed My Legs
entry.content:
I ran a little bit too hard today.

Today I was working on my half marathon goal. I found out the block that I live on has an almost perfect 2 mile loop. It makes things perfect for calculating pace and distance without bringing up Google maps.

Yesterday I ran 2 miles at a 9:30 min/mile pace. Today, even though I was pretty sore from yesterday, decided to up my pace to a 9:00 min/mile pace for two miles. My quads are killing me.

It's a good thing though, as long as I don't overdo it. The last thing I need to do is injure myself and not achieve my goal. I've gotta crawl before I walk, and walk before I run.

A 9:00 pace is almost overkill if I just want to get under two hours. I think that's a reasonable goal to have. I'd rather be over prepared than under prepared.

We have plenty of time until September though. I'm not too worried at all about making the progress we need to get the time we want.

It's late. Short post tonight.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 13: Lightbulb
entry.content:
I search the internet a lot for ways that I can start freelancing my web development. Most people say not to do it because it is hard.

I'm not afraid of hard at all. I am chasing success, and I have goals that I am setting for myself.

Yesterday I was thinking about how I could charge people for my time, and I was wondering if there was a way that I could accelerate my time by automating tasks. Turns out, you can, and it's awesome!

Enter Yeoman (with grunt/gulp and bower). The scaffolding and package manager combination makes it an amazing tool for automating my workflow.

I plan on using it to  convert this blog over to a jekyll blog, and I plan on making my own bootstrap generators so that I can have my own themes.

This will also help me get a better feel for design and the time it takes to make a website from scratch for a client. Plus, I will have designs ready and automated with colors to show clients.

When I first stumbled upon things like yeoman and gulp and npm and the like, I didn't really understand them because I wasn't coming at it from a perspective of  automating my workflow.

I'm excited to keep learning and improving so that I can begin to supplement my income in the way that I want.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 12: The Root
entry.content:
What caused me to set the goals that I have set?

That's a good question, considering that if I couldn't answer it, my priorities would be unfounded.

I have a lot of debt. About $150k. It makes you feel stuck. It stunts your growth. I need to accelerate my payments and get it out of my life. That's why I would like to supplement my income.

I'm getting older, and getting weaker. I also am aware of the positive links between being fit and how healthy your brain is. That's why I would like to get fit.

I have not been living my life intentionally with my current relationships. I constantly am wishing I would do more with my friends and family that matters. And really, they are the ones in my life who matter. That's why I'd like to deepen those relationships.

I have been slacking at work. I talked a little bit about why in my last post, but that's really no excuse. It's not who I want to be. That's why I'd like to work harder at work.

I have not been reading enough. Faith comes by hearing and hearing comes by the Word of God. By not reading my Bible, I am not contributing to my faith, and therefore I cannot expect all that God has promised will take place in my lifetime. Knowledge is power, and by reading I can acquire knowledge. That's why I would like to read more.

I have hardly any control over where my time is being spent. My priorities are out of whack, and I waste days away like nobody's business. That really needs to end. That's why I'd like to get better at time management.

It's pretty easy for me to point out the reasons behind the things that I want to achieve in the near future, and I think that is a good thing. 

Saying something and doing it are two completely different things. I want to be a man of my word, and do what I say I will do. 

I want to look back at my life and have as few regrets as possible. I want to reap what I have sown and see the fruit of my labor. I want to be the hardest working person I know, all while being the most invested in his relationships.

It's going to take a while for me to get there, but I will. You have my word.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 11: Transitions
entry.content:
I think I need to rant a little bit.

I have been relatively successful at work. For my age and experience, I have been put in some pretty tight situations where product getting shipped out the door depended on me.

I had been working as an intern under my boss, who is an electro-optical engineer. He is amazing, and I learn from him every day. He is my mentor.

Then, in July, I was hired on full time as a salary employee. Since then, there been been some changes. Changes that I don't think I like.

I was slowly transitioned from being my boss's protege to being part of a different group in the building. This group prides themselves on being different from the rest of the company, and tends to be quite exclusive. I'm now a half-breed. Something in-between both groups.

On one hand, it was exciting and a new challenge to get on the team. However, there is a certain culture that hasn't really sat well with me. I haven't been able to quite put my finger on it.

Everything the group does is collaborative - whether the person knows anything about the subject or not, they are expected to give their input. I find this weird. I don't know everything, so I don't want to speak when I have no idea what I am talking about.

Don't get me wrong, collaboration is a great thing. But, I think there comes a point where certain decisions can be made because they were made by a professional that knows what they are doing.

There is also a social element that I haven't been able to crack. The exclusivity of the group is a cool branding, but I'm not particularly friends with any of them. The ones that I am friends with want out - I'm pretty sure of that.

The group also seems like somewhat a venture of the vision for the company, and they don't make a ton of money. I'm not exactly proud of the work that they produce, and it seems some of the tools/solutions they use are somewhat dated and a bear to use.

My cubicle was moved closer to this new group. I miss the nuances and conversations with my mentor and the group he is a part of.

All of this contributes to a feeling I have had for the past several weeks. I want out. I'm not comfortable where I am at, and I want to go back to the way it was. I still need to be mentored.

This past week, I had a meeting with my old group. The one where I was always under my mentor. It was great. There were so many brilliant minds in the room. I felt really important to still be a part of the group.

I can't really find any positive reasons, both socially and career wise, there would be to staying with this new group. I just don't fit. I think I will have a conversation with my engineering manager about it this week.

If he can give me some good advice on the path that I should choose, then I will listen. Otherwise, I think I should go with my gut on this one. Things just aren't working.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 10: The Art of Procrastination
entry.content:
I am a chronic procrastinator.

I watched an amazing TED talk about procrastination today. You can watch it here.

He talks a lot about why procrastinators are the way they are, but it was his point at the end of the video that struck me the most.

You see, procrastination isn't so bad when there is a deadline. I would wait until the last minute to write a lab report or study for a test. It always worked out okay.

The big problem for procrastinators is when they want to get something done that has no deadline. There is no sense of urgency or panic that kicks in.

That's why it is so important for me to learn how to plan. If I can't plan for things that have no deadline, then I will never even start them.

It's simple but it gets fuzzy for me sometimes

I have had some success with working out for my marathon because I have both a deadline and a plan that I am using. It makes my part easy - just do what it says. 

Things like supplementing my income, building relationships, reading more and doing better at work have no deadline and no plan. How do I even remotely expect to succeed without a written plan?

I need dates, I need steps and then I need to take action. As long as I have the other things in place, I don't think that it is too hard for me to take action.

I will be developing specific plans in the future. These plans will need to be tested and adjusted, but they will help me get over the hump of never achieving what I want to because I procrastinate so long.

I need to be the one to initiate and start planning these activities. No one is going to do them for me, and no one is going to care if I don't succeed, because I will still be just average default Jordan.

In the next coming days expect written plans. If I don't deliver, someone please hold me accountable.

Jordan.

entry.title: Day 9: How to Not be a Miserable Failure
entry.content:
The key to not being a miserable failure is to be ready before you need to be.

I was supposed to start fasting today. It was going well, at first. I made it past lunch and even into the evening. It was then that I realized that I was in over my head.

The last time I had fasted was back in college. I had several advantages then. I was more healthy, had less responsibilities and I had a friend to do it with.

Today I am fatter than I want to be, I have an 8 - 5 job that people depend on me to get done, and I am doing it alone. It's much different from my last scenario.

So, I gave in and had dinner tonight. I felt bad, but my brain thanked me. One of the major points of fasting is prayer and reading, and I was doing the reading but not the praying.

I think this was a big reason why I had success before. I was good at 'praying without ceasing'. It was natural for me. Lately, it's not even on my mind.

I think I had it backwards when I thought that fasting would put me in a place of somewhat redemption. In reality, in order to have a successful fast, my heart and mind need to be in the right place.

That makes my priority list all the more important. I should have my priorities in place before I need them.

I heard on the EntreLeadership podcast by Dave Ramsey today, "The easiest time to build relationships is before you need them." That was a really eye opening quote for me.

Building relationships has always been hard for me. But I'm finding out that relationships are everything and are the only thing worth anything in this life outside of hard work.

I think the best route for me is a period of transition that will allow me to become the person that I want to be. I would like to be able to fast purposefully every month in the future. But I can't do that if I am not ready.

That also leads me to another point, which is one of faith. Part of the reason fasting is implemented is because of how hard it is, and how you have to give up on your own strength and depend on God's.

That's where a strong prayer link comes in. If I'm not praying, then fasting is going to be a miserable, fleshly failure.

The key to not being a miserable failure is to be ready before you need to be.

This feels good.

Jordan

link.title: Day 9: How to Not be a Miserable Failure

entry.title: Day 8: Pre-game
entry.content:
Today is the last day before I start a week long fast of both food and digital entertainment/social media. It's extreme, but I think it will be awesome.

I'm ready for a good reset. I haven't done a week long fast in a few years. I remember the profound impact it had on me back then.

I plan on fasting more often. I think it is good to keep thing fresh and have a clean slate to work with. Coupled with being in the word and prayer time, it is truly the best way to spiritually align with the plan that God has for your life.

Having an entertainment/social media fast will impact me both at work and at home. At work, when things are slow, I default to going on YouTube and read articles about anything and everything.

It's not necessarily bad entertainment, but the default behavior is unacceptable in my eyes and my work ethic suffers for it. I feel that I need to show the people I work with that I can do above and beyond the things that they ask me to do.

Part of the time I gain while fasting I would like to use for reading and planning. I want to read my Bible more, and also plan on how to tackle some of the things I have mentioned in previous posts.

I will continue posting throughout the fast. It'll help me document how I feel and what I think.

This feels good.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 7: Can't Stop Me Now
entry.content:
A Whole Week

I don't remember the last time that happened


I'm pretty happy with myself for sticking this out for a whole week already. Its nothing major, but it points out that I can actually accomplish something that I set out to do.

All of this last week's blog posts have been a brain dump to get my priorities straight. They have been mostly critical and focused on a negative aspect of my life. 

I don't want things to always be like that. I am not always going to have the same problems over and over again. I am going to continue to grow.

I think the goal for this blog is to use it as a platform for acknowledging the things I need to work on, creating a written path as to how I will change that thing, making note about the process and then sharing my success after I feel like I have successfully changed that thing.

I also would like to use this blog as a platform to inspire and help other people that want to get their lives in order. I want other people to want to live their life as their best self, not someone who doesn't aspire to their dreams.

I want to live intentionally. I don't want to just let life happen to me. I think that is clear.

I'm going to read some books and do some research on things that can help me do that. I know I will need my wife's help as well. 

Right now I am reading EntreLeadership by Dave Ramsey because I think that I would one day like to own my own company and work for myself. 

I would like to get the book: Living Forward by Michael Hyatt, which talks about living intentionally. 

As always, I will post my progress here. 

This feels good.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 6: Estimating vs. Planning
entry.content:
Estimating

To my demise


I used to pride myself in the ability to estimate just about anything, even without a lot of prior knowledge in a subject. I can gauge a lot by how a question is asked, phrased and emphasized.

Growing up I applied this to a lot of things. It helps make you appear to learn faster than everyone else, and sound way smarter than you actually are. 

Precision was never really something that interested me. If I could get close enough faster than anyone else, that was good enough. It worked for a while.

What I didn't realize is that my ability to estimate was diminishing my ability to be precise and follow a plan of action to a specific result.

To this day I can't divide two numbers on paper. I do it all in my head - and if the scope is reasonable, it works great. Until the scope is unreasonable.

I can't estimate what my life is going to be like in 10 years. I can hardly estimate what my life will be like after one year. This lack of specificity has made it so not only can I not follow a life plan, I can't create one either.

I'm 'good' at budgeting our expenses because I can estimate quick numbers in my head, but I don't have a specific plan to actually get a desired result. I just hope it works out based on what I estimated.

This attitude/default tendency in my life needs to not be used so much. It's keeping me from reaching specific results that I want to achieve. I come up with a goal and then I just hope it happens. 

My life needs to be intentional and specific. Not a product of hoping things work out like I thought they would.

This concept may be simple for some people, and that's fine. But it is nearly impossible for me. I am always easy on myself, I'm always prone to make the rules bend in my favor. 

Specific planning needs to be a default tendency of mine. I need to be intentional about my actions and decisions. I also need to be intentional about my priorities. It's crucial for me to stop guessing about my future.

It's time I acknowledged that even because I can get close, that's not the real thing. Close to a great life is not a great life. Close to creating my own wealth is not creating my own wealth. Close to working hard is not working hard. 

I need to figure out how to plan, and be able to follow a plan to the T.

This feels good.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 5: 6th Item
entry.content:
Another Thing

Perhaps the most important thing


On Day 2: TIMU I listed out the things that I would like to accomplish. Then, in Day 3, I talked about some ways to try and tackle those things.

Yesterday I was my old default self. Except my main issue was something I hadn't discussed yet. I have no concept of time management.

I am way too obsessive about the thing that I am working on currently. I think this is both really good and potentially really bad. I am passionate about my work and I am somewhat of a perfectionist of the things that I have control over.

This passion causes me to have big goals and dreams. It causes me to work harder and put my nose to the grinder every day.

This passion causes me to neglect other aspects of my life. It causes me to ignore my priorities and render them useless. 

This fundamental issue has inhibited my ability to manage some of the things that I want to accomplish. It makes me stay up late working on something when I need to go to bed. It makes me neglect other things long enough to the point that there are issues. It makes me skip meals when I need nutrition to complete my workouts.

My time management always needs to be in check with my priorities. If I haven't consulted them first, then I have no grounds for dedicating time to it. 

I might do some research on time management and how to make sure they are in line with my priorities. It is important that this aspect of my life gets under control.

Yet another thing

I am going to do a fast next week from internet related entertainment, and food as well. This will put my workouts on hold, but I think it is a good thing to do for a complete reset of my priorities.

I already got rid of the apps that take up most of my time on my phone, but I still need to get in the right mindset about the changes I am making. 

So that will be next week, days 8 - 14. It is meant to be a physical, mental and spiritual reset on myself. I want to make sure I am in the right place before I set out to accomplish these things for this year.

This feels good.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 4: Reiterate
entry.content:
Reiterate My Focus

Keep it simple.


In my first post, I made the statement that "My default self needs to wake up every morning and create, not wake up and consume." I need to revisit this.

Consuming content is almost like a disease. It's the opposite of making an impact on the world - rather, it is making an impact on you.

The content we consume was originally created by someone who took the time and energy to create it. Whether it be art, social posts, information, news, etc., someone made it.

My simplistic goal is to create more, do more and be more. The same thing could be said in this way: My simplistic goal is to consume less, relax less and be less comfortable with who I am.

I really think that I don't need to consume any content. No social media, no tech videos, no vloggers, no news articles. It's just not necessary at the rate we are accustomed to.

My focus is to eventually become the content that people are consuming. My focus is to make an impact on the world, not just let it make an impact on me.

This simple switch will easily give me more time, more energy and more focus on the things that I want to achieve. How can it not?

I'm ready for a big switch in my daily routine, and I think this is a big step.

I'm not banning all content from my life, I'm just going to change the flow direction from consume to create. Part of changing that flow might be stopping the flow all together initially. A reset.

I'm at a unique place in my life where I am sill able to mold my future. There are a lot of things set in stone, but that just helps me focus even more because I don't have to think about accomplishing those things.

I want to mold my future into one of productivity, creativity and enjoyment. A future that I can plan in advance, while being bold enough to have absolutely no idea what will happen next.

Work harder. Do more.

This feels good.

Jordan

entry.title: Day 3: Someone Who Does
entry.content:
I almost forgot to do this tonight.

It's late.


My last post talked about the things that I plan on doing. This one will talk about some plans to achieve those things. 

I have a few things planned out, and a few things I am still working on. 

Exercise is planned out. I got an app called 'Run Trainer' and it scheduled my workout for every day up to the half marathon.

I have a few plans for learning Javascript and getting deeper into web development. Starting out I will be following a plan designed by 'Javascript Is Sexy'.

The other things I haven't planned yet and will need a bit more diligence to accomplish.

Developing deeper relationships, reading more and doing better at work all come with priority. If I don't set them at a high enough priority, they won't get done.

That means other things need to get knocked down on the list. Things like, obsessively checking instagram/reddit/google plus/meduim/feedly/facebook/youtube. I read them way too much. I'll be deleting most of those off of my phone shortly.

There are other inhibitors that aren't necessarily priorities so much as they are habits. Things like staying in my comfort zone, defaulting to laziness and distraction, and not taking time to think about my priorities and what I should actually be doing with my time.

Priorities are always something I have said is the key to my success, but have never really gotten them in order. I'm a big hypocrite like that.
